food.description: Idli or idly are a type of savoury rice cake, originating from the Indian subcontinent, popular as breakfast foods in Southern India and among Tamils in Sri Lanka. The cakes are made by steaming a batter consisting of fermented black lentils (de-husked) and rice.

food.recipe: To make this easy Jalebi recipe, mix together all-purpose flour, cornflour and baking soda in a bowl. Now, add ghee and food colour in the above mixture. To make a thick batter add hung curd and water.
food.step 1: in a mixing bowl, mix maida, corn flour, curd.
food.step 2: then add half tsp vinegar and water.
food.step 3: mix well in round circular directions for 4 minutes.
food.step 4: now add baking soda and give a gentle mix.
food.step 5: now pour this batter in the tomato ketchup bottles carefully.
food.step6: heat oil in a pan and add 1 tbsp of ghee.
food.step7: squeeze the bottle and make round spirals with the batter.
food.step8: when one side is partly cooked, turn over and fry the other side.
food.step9: fry till the jalebis are a light golden.
food.step10: then immediately drop the fried jalebis in the warm sugar syrup for 30 seconds (1 string consistency).
food.step11: finally, serve jalebis hot, warm or at room temperature.
food.ingredients: ½ cup all purpose flour / maida
food.ingredient 2: 1 tsp corn flour1 tsp corn flour
food.ingredient 5: 1 tsp yogurt / curd1 tsp yogurt / curd
food.ingredient 7: ⅛ tsp turmeric powder / haldi / yellow food colour, optional
food.ingredient 10: ¼ tsp saffron strands / kesar, optional
food.restaurants: ["Lashkara By Punjab Sweet House","Urban Tadka","Rabdi Wala"]
food.description: Jalebi, also known as zulbia, jilapi and zalabia, is an Indian sweet popular all over South Asia and the Middle East. It is made by deep-frying maida flour batter in pretzel or circular shapes, which are then soaked in sugar syrup. They are particularly popular in the Indian subcontinent and Iran

food.recipe: Learn to master this Japanese classic dish in your own home! Get ready to whip a lot of egg whites to create this exciting jiggly texture as well as layer in flavors like cream cheese.
food.step 1: Preheat the oven to 320°F (160°C).
food.step 2: In a small pot over medium heat, whisk together the butter, cream cheese, and milk until melted and smooth. Remove from the heat and let cool.
food.step 3: In a large bowl, whisk the egg yolks until smooth, then slowly drizzle in the cream cheese mixture, stirring until evenly combined
food.step 4: Sift in the flour and the cornstarch, whisking to make sure there are no lumps.
food.step 5: In another large bowl, beat the egg whites with a hand mixer until soft peaks form. Gradually add the sugar while continuing to beat until stiff peaks form.
food.step6: Fold about ¼ of the egg whites and into the yolk mixture, then repeat with the remaining egg whites until the batter is evenly combined.
food.step7: Grease the bottom of a 9 x 3-inch (23 x 7.5 cm) round cake pan, then line the bottom and sides with parchment paper. If using a springform pan, make sure to wrap the bottom and sides completely in foil twice to prevent any leakage.
food.step8: Pour the batter into the pan and shake to release any large air bubbles.
food.step9: Place the pan into a larger baking dish lined with 2 paper towels at the bottom. The paper towels ensure that the heat is distributed evenly along the bottom of the pan. Fill the larger pan about 1-inch (2-cm) high with hot water.
food.step10: Bake for 25 minutes, then reduce the heat to 285°F (140°C), and bake for another 55 minutes, until the cake has risen to almost double its original height.
food.step11: Remove from oven, and carefully invert the cake onto your dominant hand and peel off the paper. Be extremely careful, the cake will be hot. You can also invert the cake onto a plate, but this will cause the cake to deflate more.
food.step12: Dust the top of the cake with powdered sugar, then slice and serve with strawberries while still warm!
food.step13: Enjoy!
food.description: Japanese cheesecakes are much lighter and softer than other cheesecakes, as an effect of the beaten egg whites, as the other user mentioned. ... Furthermore, the cheese content is also lower than traditional cheesecakes, so the taste is more like a very moist, airy and fluffy sponge-cake with a hint of cream cheese.

food.recipe: Karanji is a crisp flaky fried pastry stuffed with desiccated coconut and dry fruits. it is also one of the sweet snack that is a part of Diwali faral.
food.step 1: Heat ghee in a small frying pan.
food.step 2: Add the desiccated coconut and saute stirring often till the coconut turns golden.
food.step 3: Remove the coconut and keep aside.
food.step 4: In the same pan, add the sesame seeds and roast till they pop and change color. Keep aside.
food.step 5: In a dry grinder or coffee grinder, grind the almonds, cashews, raisins to a semi fine powder.
food.step6: You can also chop these dry fruits. If you want, you can also roast the dry fruits and then chop or powder them.
food.step7: Add this dry fruits powder to the sesame seeds and coconut mixture.
food.step8: Add powdered sugar, nutmeg powder and cardamom powder.
food.step9: Mix everything well and keep the stuffing aside.
food.step10: Heat the ghee first. Just lightly heat it.
food.step11: In a bowl or pan, take the flour. Add the hot melted ghee and salt. Just lightly mix everything.
food.step12: Add milk in parts and knead the dough till smooth.
food.step13: Cover the dough with a moist kitchen towel and keep aside for 15 to 20 mins.
food.ingredient 6: 4 green cardamoms powdered or ½ teaspoon cardamom powder
food.ingredient 7: 3 tablespoon powdered sugar or as required
food.ingredient 8: a pinch of nutmeg powder or grated nutmeg
food.ingredient 10: 2 cups all purpose flour2 cups all purpose flour
food.ingredient 13: ½ cup + 1 tablespoon milk or as required
food.description: A gujiya or a pedakiya is a sweet deep-fried dumpling, native to the Indian subcontinent, made with suji or maida stuffed with a mixture of sweetened khoa and dried fruits, and fried in ghee. It is common in North India, particularly in Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan.

food.recipe: Summers and kulfi go together for us. So whenever the Indian summers arrive kulfi also starts beckoning. Its just like summers are best to make pickles and papads. In a similar way kulfis are best in the summer.
food.step 1: Take saffron and almond milk in a pan.
food.step 2: Heat on a low flame. just let the almond milk come to a gentle heat. don't boil the almond milk.
food.step 3: If using cow's milk then simmer on a low flame for about 15 to 18 mins
food.step 4: Add sugar. Stir till the sugar has dissolved.
food.step 5: Dissolve the rice flour in 3 tbsp milk.
food.step6: Add this rice flour paste to the milk. Keep on stirring so that no lumps are formed.
food.step7: Cook on a low flame. Stir in between.
food.step8: Continue to cook till the mixture thickens. Switch off the flame.
food.step9: Add the almond paste/powder/meal or khoya/evaporated milk. Stir and let the mixture cool.
food.step10: Add the mango puree, chopped pistachio slices and mix well
food.step11: Pour mango kulfi into serving bowls or kulfi moulds. Freeze for 8-10 hours.
food.step12: Serve mango kulfi cold and sliced with topped with saffron, sliced pistachios, cardamom powder or falooda along with rose syrup.
food.ingredients: 2.5 cups cow's milk or almond milk
food.ingredient 2: 2.5 cups mango puree - approx 3 to 4 large sized alphonso mangoes can be used
food.ingredient 3: ¼ or ½ cup sugar - depends on the sweetness of the mangoes. so adjust accordingly
food.ingredient 4: 4 to 5 green cardamom crushed or ¼ teaspoon cardamom powder
food.ingredient 6: 12 to 15 unsalted pistachois - blanched or soaked, peeled and sliced. keep some for garnishing
food.ingredient 7: 2 to 3 tablespoon almond paste (almond meal) or khoya (mawa or dried evaporated milk solids) - optional
food.ingredient 8: 2.5 or 3 tablespoon rice flour or 2 tablespoon corn flour dissolved in 3 tablespoon regular milk or almond milk
food.description: Kulfi is a frozen dairy dessert originating from the Indian subcontinent in the ... The more traditional ones are cream (malai), rose, mango, cardamom (elaichi), saffron (kesar or zafran), and pistachio. There are newer variations

food.recipe: Tex-Mex styled migas are the ultimate breakfast comfort food…with a kick!
food.step 1: In a large bowl, whisk together eggs, milk, cumin, salt and pepper.  Set aside.
food.step 2: Heat oil over medium-high heat in a large sauté pan.  Add onion and jalapeño and sauté for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onion is soft and translucent.  Add garlic and sauté for 1-2 additional minutes, stirring occasionally, until the garlic is fragrant.
food.step 3: Add the egg mixture, and reduce heat to medium.  Cook for 5-6 minutes, stirring frequently, until the eggs are completely scrambled.  Stir in the tortilla chips, salsa and cheese.  Cook for 2 minutes, stirring occasionally.  Taste and season with extra salt and pepper if needed.
food.step 4: Serve warm, garnished with your desired toppings.  (I say the more, the merrier!)
food.ingredient 3: 1/2 teaspoon each: ground cumin, fine sea salt, freshly-cracked black pepper
food.ingredient 5: 1 small white onion, peeled and diced
food.ingredient 8: 2 large handfuls corn tortilla chips, roughly crumbled
food.ingredient 10: 2/3 cup shredded Mexican-blend cheese, plus extra for serving
food.ingredient 11: toppings: chopped fresh cilantro, diced red onion, sliced avocado, diced tomato, extra salsa
food.description: Migas is a dish in Spanish and Portuguese cuisines. Migas is usually served as a first course for lunch or dinner in restaurants in Spain.

food.recipe: A traditional Mexican open sandwich with refried beans and melted cheese served with salsa. Perfect for breakfast, lunch, or as a tasty snack.
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper.
food.step 2: Remove some of the bread from the middle of bread halves to accommodate more toppings. Spread about 1 teaspoon butter on each half.
food.step 3: Spread 2 to 3 tablespoons warmed refried beans on bread. Sprinkle about 1/4 cup Borden® Cheddar and Monterey Jack shredded cheese on the beans. Place bread halves on prepared baking sheet.
food.step 4: Bake in preheated oven until the cheese is melted and bubbly and the bread is crispy, 15 to 20 minutes.
food.step 5: Top molletes with Mexican salsa or pico de gallo.
food.ingredients: 4 eaches bolillo rolls, sliced in half lengthwise
food.ingredient 4: 1 (7 ounce) package Borden® Southwestern Cheddar & Monterey Jack Shredded Cheese
food.ingredient 5: Mexican salsa or pico de gallo, for serving
food.description: A mollete refers to an open-faced sandwich in Mexican cuisine or to a type of bread in Spanish cuisine.

food.recipe: Patatas bravas are one of the most beloved Spanish tapas, thanks to their simple combination of fried potatoes and flavorful sauce. Make them at home with this easy recipe!
food.step 1: Peel the potatoes, rinse thoroughly, and dry with a paper towel.
food.step 2: Cut the potatoes into bite-size chunks.
food.step 3: Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
food.step 4: Add the potatoes and adjust the heat to the lowest setting, allowing them to pre-cook for a few minutes.
food.step 5: Remove the potatoes and let them cool in the fridge for a few more minutes.
food.step6: Turn the heat up to high and add the potatoes back into the pan.
food.step7: Fry until crispy and golden.
food.step8: Transfer the potatoes to a plate lined with paper towels to cool, and sprinkle with salt to taste.
food.step9: To serve, drizzle the bravas sauce over the potatoes
food.step10: Dig in—no forks necessary!
food.ingredient 2: Olive oil for frying, about 1-2 cups
food.description: Patatas bravas, also called patatas a la brava or papas bravas, is a dish native to Spain, often served as a tapa in bars. It typically consists of white potatoes that have been cut into irregular cubes of about two centimetres, then fried in oil and served warm with a spicy sauce.

food.recipe: My homemade pecan pie is classic and simple with an unexpected dash of cinnamon. It’s the perfect combination of sweet and salty– after one bite you’ll taste why it’s my favorite!
food.step 1: The crust: Prepare my pie crust through step 5.
food.step 2: After the pie dough chills, adjust oven rack to the lower third position and preheat to 350°F (177°C).
food.step 3: Roll out the chilled pie crust onto a lightly floured surface. Remember, when rolling out the pie dough, always use gentle force with your rolling pin. Start from the center and work your way out in all directions, rotating the dough with your hands as you go. Roll it out into a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough in a 9×2 inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it’s smooth. For a beautiful edge, as shown in the video above, fold the overhanging dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a nice thick rim around the pie. Crimp the edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. Again, you can see me do this in the video above. Brush the edges with egg wash. (To help guarantee a beautiful edge, I always chill the shaped dough in the pie dish for 10 minutes in the refrigerator or freezer before filling.)
food.step 4: Bake the pie for 40-50 minutes, or until the top is lightly browned. After the first 20 minutes of bake time, I place a pie crust shield on top of the pie to prevent the edges from browning too quickly. You can also tent a piece of aluminum foil over the whole pie if it is browning too quickly. Remove finished pie from the oven and place on a wire rack to cool completely. The pie filling will settle as it cools.
food.step 5: Slice and serve pie warm or at room temperature. Top with whipped cream or ice cream.
food.step6: Cover and store leftovers at room temperature for 1-2 days or in the refrigerator for 4-5 days.
food.ingredients: 2 and 1/2 cups (250g) coarsely chopped pecans (a very rough chop!
food.description: A Southern staple for decades, this delicious pie has become wildly popular in recent years.

food.recipe: Garlic chicken, or pollo al ajillo, is a classic Spanish recipe. Even though it hails from the Andalusian region, it is enjoyed all over Spain. This version is cooked on the stove rather than roasted in the oven.
food.step 1: Gather the ingredients.
food.step 2: Cut chicken into 10 to 12 pieces. Rinse and pat dry. Place the chicken in a large glass dish and squeeze lemon juice over it.
food.step 3: Peel 2 garlic cloves and chop finely. Rub the garlic, salt, and pepper into the chicken. Marinate for 1 to 2 hours.
food.step 4: In a large, heavy-bottomed frying pan, pour 3/4 cup of the olive oil and heat over medium heat.
food.step 5: Remove the chicken from the marinade and drain well. Place the chicken in the hot oil and brown on both sides.
food.step6: Remove the chicken from the frying pan and place in a Dutch oven or a covered, deep frying pan. Add the white wine and bay leaf. Cover and simmer on low until the wine is reduced.
food.step7: While the chicken simmers, peel and cut the potatoes into thin round slices or small cubes.
food.step8: In a small frying pan, heat the remaining 3/4 cup olive oil on medium high and fry the potatoes. Remove potatoes and add them to the chicken. If more sauce is desired, add the cup of broth now. Reduce the heat to low and continue to simmer, covered.
food.step9: Finely chop the parsley and sprinkle over chicken.
food.step10: Peel the remaining 4 cloves of garlic and cut into thin slices. In the same pan used to brown the chicken, lightly sauté the garlic, and add the hot pepper, if using. Add Spanish paprika, vinegar, and sugar.
food.step11: Stir, scraping the bottom of the pan. Pour over the chicken. Adjust the seasoning to taste, and serve
food.ingredient 9: 1 1/2 pounds potatoes (about 4 medium potatoes; peeled, sliced or cubed)
food.description: Pollo Al Ajillo (Classic Spanish Garlic Chicken) Garlic chicken, or pollo al ajillo, is a classic Spanish recipe. Even though it hails from the Andalusian region, it is enjoyed all over Spain. This version is cooked on the stove rather than roasted in the oven.

food.recipe: This is absolutely the BEST homemade pumpkin pie recipe! Make it with canned or fresh pumpkin puree and up to several days ahead. Also freezes well! Thanksgiving pie never looked so good or so easy
food.step 1: Preheat your oven to 425°F.
food.step 2: Make the filling: Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the brown sugar, white sugar, salt, spices—cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, ground cloves, cardamom, and lemon zest.
food.step 3: Mix in the pumpkin purée. Stir in the cream. Beat together until everything is well mixed.
food.step 4: Pour into pie shell and bake: Pour the filling into an uncooked chilled or frozen pie shell. Bake at a high temperature of 425°F for 15 minutes.
food.step 5: Then after 15 minutes, lower the temperature to 350°F. Bake for 45 to 55 minutes more. The pie is done when a knife tip inserted in the center comes out wet but relatively clean. The center should be just barely jiggly.
food.step6: Cool on a rack: Cool the pumpkin pie on a wire rack for 2 hours. Note that the pumpkin pie will come out of the oven all puffed up (from the leavening of the eggs), and will deflate as it cools.
food.step7: Serve with whipped cream.
food.ingredients: 2 large eggs plus the yolk of a third egg
food.ingredient 11: 1 good pie crust, chilled or frozen (see pâte brisée recipe or our no-fail flaky pie crust recipe)
food.description: Pumpkin pie. Pumpkin pie is a dessert pie with a spiced, pumpkin-based custard filling. The pumpkin is a symbol of harvest time, and pumpkin pie is often eaten during the fall and early winter. In the United States and Canada, it is usually prepared for Thanksgiving, and other occasions when pumpkin is in season.

food.recipe: Absolutely amazing! I used a mandolin to keep the slices extra and evenly thin. Came out just like the movie ratatouille
food.step 1: Preheat the oven for 375˚F (190˚C).
food.step 2: Slice the eggplant, tomatoes, squash, and zucchini into approximately ¹⁄₁₆-inch (1-mm) rounds, then set aside.
food.step 3: Make the sauce: Heat the olive oil in a 12-inch (30-cm) oven-safe pan over medium-high heat. Sauté the onion, garlic, and bell peppers until soft, about 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper, then add the crushed tomatoes. Stir until the ingredients are fully incorporated. Remove from heat, then add the basil. Stir once more, then smooth the surface of the sauce with a spatula.
food.step 4: Arrange the sliced veggies in alternating patterns, (for example, eggplant, tomato, squash, zucchini) on top of the sauce from the outer edge to the middle of the pan. Season with salt and pepper.
food.step 5: Make the herb seasoning: In a small bowl, mix together the basil, garlic, parsley, thyme, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Spoon the herb seasoning over the vegetables.
food.step6: Cover the pan with foil and bake for 40 minutes. Uncover, then bake for another 20 minutes, until the vegetables are softened.
food.step7: Serve while hot as a main dish or side. The ratatouille is also excellent the next day--cover with foil and reheat in a 350˚F (180˚C) oven for 15 minutes, or simply microwave to desired temperature.
food.step8: Enjoy!
food.ingredient 12: 28 oz can of crushed tomatoes (795 g)
food.ingredient 13: 2 tablespoons chopped fresh basil, from 8-10 leaves
food.ingredient 14: 2 tablespoons chopped fresh basil, from 8-10 leaves
food.description: Ratatouille is a French Provençal stewed vegetable dish, originating in Nice. This dish is an easy mix of seasonal vegetables, garlic, and olive oil.

food.recipe: Place 4 eggs in a small saucepan; add cold water to cover. Bring to a boil; remove from heat, cover, and let stand for 3 minutes. Carefully drain, then fill pan with ice water to cool eggs
food.step 1: Preheat the oven for 375˚F (190˚C).
food.step 2: Slice the eggplant, tomatoes, squash, and zucchini into approximately ¹⁄₁₆-inch (1-mm) rounds, then set aside.
food.step 3: Make the sauce: Heat the olive oil in a 12-inch (30-cm) oven-safe pan over medium-high heat. Sauté the onion, garlic, and bell peppers until soft, about 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper, then add the crushed tomatoes. Stir until the ingredients are fully incorporated. Remove from heat, then add the basil. Stir once more, then smooth the surface of the sauce with a spatula.
food.step 4: Arrange the sliced veggies in alternating patterns, (for example, eggplant, tomato, squash, zucchini) on top of the sauce from the outer edge to the middle of the pan. Season with salt and pepper.
food.step 5: Make the herb seasoning: In a small bowl, mix together the basil, garlic, parsley, thyme, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Spoon the herb seasoning over the vegetables.
food.step6: Cover the pan with foil and bake for 40 minutes. Uncover, then bake for another 20 minutes, until the vegetables are softened.
food.step7: Serve while hot as a main dish or side. The ratatouille is also excellent the next day--cover with foil and reheat in a 350˚F (180˚C) oven for 15 minutes, or simply microwave to desired temperature.

food.description: A Scotch egg consists of a whole soft or hard-boiled egg wrapped in sausage meat, coated in bread crumbs and baked or deep-fried.

food.recipe: Experiment with Southern-style coating on prawns, instead of chicken. These moreish prawns have a crispy, spicy coating and taste great with a hot gumbo dip and lemon wedges
food.step 1: To prepare the prawns, mix the buttermilk, garlic granules and ground ginger together in a bowl. Add the prawns and stir to coat, then chill for at least 30 mins or overnight.
food.step 2: Meanwhile, make the coating by combining all of the ingredients with a pinch of salt in a shallow dish. Set aside.
food.step 3: Allow any excess buttermilk marinade to drip off the prawns, then dip in the coating mixture, turning to ensure an even covering.
food.step 4: Heat a deep-fat fryer no more than a third full of oil to 180C. Or, heat the oil to a depth of 10cm in a pan until a cube of bread sizzles and turns golden in 30 seconds. Carefully lower 3-4 prawns into the oil at a time and deep-fry for 2 mins, or until crisp and golden. Transfer to a plate lined with kitchen paper using a slotted spoon, then season and sprinkle with the coriander leaves and lemon zest, if you like. Serve with the hot gumbo dip (see below) and some lemon wedges for squeezing over.
food.ingredient 2: ½ bunch of coriander , leaves picked, to serve
food.ingredient 3: 1 lemon , zested (optional) and cut into wedges to serve
food.ingredient 7: 18 jumbo raw prawns , head left on, tails peeled, butterflied

food.recipe: Gelato is made differently than Ice cream, it’s denser and creamier, and the flavors are more intense than regular ice cream. The reason for this is due to a very important ingredient – air. American ice cream can contain up to 50% air. This results in a lighter airier texture.
food.step 1: Remove the stems and leaves from the strawberries and rinse in cold water.
food.step 2: Place the strawberries, lemon juice and the sugar in a food processor and process until liquefied.
food.step 3: Add the water and run the food processor until all the mixture is smooth.
food.step 4: Whip the cream with a wire whisk until it begins to thicken slightly and becomes the consistency of buttermilk.
food.step 5: Mix the cream and strawberry mixture in a bowl and mix thoroughly.
food.step6: Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and freeze following the manufacturer’s instructions.
food.description: Strawberry ice cream is a flavor of ice cream made with strawberry or strawberry flavoring. It is made by blending in fresh strawberries or strawberry flavoring with the eggs, cream, vanilla and sugar used to make ice cream. Most strawberry ice cream is colored pink or light red.

food.recipe: A cheesy potato and bacon casserole—this is what I crave after a long day of skiing to warm me up. The dish derives from Savoy in the Alps and always reminds me of my favorite time (the holidays, of course) in winter. I recommend serving it with a leafy green salad dressed with an acidic vinaigrette to balance out the fattiness of the reblochon cheese
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 200°C/400°F. Add potatoes to a pot of cold water. The water should be enough to cover the potatoes. Season with salt, then bring to a boil over medium-high heat and let boil for approx. 10 - 15 min., or until fork tender. Drain and let cool.
food.step 2: In the meantime, peel and mince onions and garlic. Roughly chop bacon. Heat olive oil in a large pan over medium heat and sauté bacon and onions for approx. 3 min. Add garlic and sauté for 2 min. more. Deglaze with white wine and let cook for approx. 2 min.
food.step 3: Peel and slice cooked, cooled potatoes. Add half of the potato slices to a baking dish. Season with salt and pepper and top with half of the bacon-onion mixture. Layer over half the sliced Reblochon and repeat the process with remaining ingredients. Cover with milk and bake at 200ºC/400ºF for approx. 30 – 40 min., until the top is golden brown. Enjoy!
food.description: Tartiflette is a dish from Savoy in the Alps. It is made with potatoes, reblochon cheese, lardons and onions. The word tartiflette is probably derived from the Arpitan word for potato, tartiflâ.

food.recipe: From Badmaash restaurant, in Los Angeles, this aromatic tea, called "cutting chai" in India, is served in small glasses because it's so strong ("cutting" is the transliteration of the Hindi word for "half"). The black cardamom gives it a smoky, earthy flavor; we recommend starting with the lower amount
food.step 1: Pour 2 cups water into a medium saucepan and add tea and spices. Bring to a boil over high heat and boil 2 minutes.
food.step 2: add sugar and milk and return to a boil. Reduce heat to medium and boil gently 2 minutes, stirring occasionally. Strain and pour into small cups or heatproof glasses.
food.step 3: Find black cardamom in the spice aisle of well-stocked supermarkets, at Indian markets, and at worldspice.com.
food.ingredients: 4 teaspoons loose-leaf black tea, such as Assam
food.ingredient 2: 1 or 2 cinnamon sticks (each about 2 1/2 in. long)
food.ingredient 3: 1 or 2 black (also called brown) cardamom* pods, crushed with a rolling pin or mallet
food.ingredient 4: 2 to 4 green cardamom pods, crushed with a rolling pin or mallet
food.restaurants: ["Kripa Sagar Pure Veg Restaurant","Delhi Drum","Shree Foods","Maheshwari dosa"]
food.description: An British all time favourite consumed either as industrial strength, brewed and steeped for hours from a tea-bag (or several), or in a more refined, loose leaf, afternoon earl grey type of way.

food.recipe: These Thai chicken lettuce wraps are bursting with bold flavor, and fresh ingredients. They can be enjoyed as a main dish or served as an appetizer.
food.step 1: Heat oil in a large skillet over medium.
food.step 2: Add chicken, garlic, onions, salt and pepper and cook, tossing occasionally, until chicken is cooked through.
food.step 3: Add the carrots, cabbage, and green onions, and cook for 2 more minutes.
food.step 4: In a small bowl combine the sweet chili sauce, ginger, peanut butter, soy sauce, and crushed red pepper. Stir until smooth.
food.step 5: Add sauce to the pan. Add cilantro. toss everything until combined.
food.step6: Spoon mixture into individual lettuce cups. Should fill about 8 lettuce cups.
food.step7: You might also like Cashew Chicken Lettuce Wraps!
food.ingredient 2: 1/2 pound boneless skinless chicken breasts (or tenders), chopped into very small pieces*
food.ingredient 15: crushed red pepper flakes to tastecrushed red pepper flakes
food.description: Lean pork, low-sodium soy sauce, and plenty of fresh vegetables make these a great low-carb, low-calorie snack at any time of the day.

food.recipe: This vegan fried okra is simple to make and perfect for when you’re craving something crispy, fatty and salty. I ain’t gonna lie, this is no health food but just cuz we’re vegan doesn’t mean we can’t enjoy some southern fried comfort food from time to time,
food.step 1: Heat about 2.5 cm (1/2 inch) of oil in a small frying pan over medium heat
food.step 2: Put the apple cider vinegar into a measuring cup and add soy milk to make ¼ (60 ml) cup. Transfer to a bowl.
food.step 3: In a separate bowl combine the cornmeal, flour, garlic powder, cayenne, salt and pepper.
food.step 4: Test the oil by dipping a wooden chopstick in it. If the oil bubbles up around it, it’s hot enough. Work in small batches and dip the some okra first into the buttermilk, then transfer a few pieces at a time to the flour mixture and roll to cover. Fry, turning as necessary until golden brown on all sides. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain. (I found it easier to transfer the okra pieces in and out of the oil with chopsticks).
food.step 5: If you want you can sprinkle a bit more salt over the hot okra (optional). Serve warm
food.ingredient 3: A scant ¼ cup (60 ml) unsweetened soy milk (or other plant-based milk)
food.ingredient 8: ¼ teaspoon salt (plus more for sprinkling)
food.ingredient 10: 1 ½ cups (130 grams) sliced fresh okra

food.recipe: Veg Chow Mein is a very tasty and popular stir-fried vegetable noodle dish from China. It’s also one of the most popular street foods in India and a lot of other countries.
food.step 1: Boil the noodles as per instructions given on the packet. Rinse with cold water, apply some oil to avoid sticking and keep aside.
food.step 2: In a bowl mix all the sauces, vinegar, pepper, and salt. Keep aside
food.step 3: Heat oil in a large wok or pan. Add garlic, saute for a few seconds till they become fragrant.
food.step 4: Add the sliced onion and stir fry till it becomes translucent and then add all the remaining vegetables and white portion of spring onion. Stir fry for around 2-3 minutes or till vegetables are cooked but crunchy.
food.step 5: Add the sauce mixture, mix and stir fry for a few seconds before adding the noodles. Stir fry for another 2 minutes, tossing continuously till everything gets mixed nicely.
food.step6: Garnish with the green part of spring onions and serve hot.

food.recipe: AMBROSIA SALAD IS A STAPLE SIDE DISH THAT’S BEEN AROUND FOR YEARS! THIS RECIPE IS SUPER SIMPLE TO MAKE, AND ALWAYS A CROWD-PLEASER
food.step 1: In a clean, medium-sized bowl, combine the heavy cream, powdered sugar, and vanilla extract.
food.step 2: Use an electric mixer to beat on high speed until stiff peaks have formed (mixture should reach a Cool Whip consistency).
food.step 3: Add sour cream and stir until well-combined.
food.step 4: In a separate, large bowl, combine mini marshmallows, coconut, oranges, maraschino cherries, and pineapple. Stir to combine.
food.step 5: Pour whipped cream/sour cream mixture over ingredients and stir until everything is evenly combined and all ingredients are covered in the cream mixture.
food.step6: Cover and refrigerate at least one hour before serving.
food.description: Ambrosia is an American variety of fruit salad. Most ambrosia recipes contain: canned or fresh pineapple, canned mandarin orange slices or fresh orange sections, miniature marshmallows, and coconut.

food.recipe: oven barbecue ribs slathered in the most delicious sticky barbecue sauce with a kick of garlic and optional heat
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C)
food.step 2: Peel off tough membrane that covers the underside/bony side of the ribs. Place on a baking sheet or tray lined with foil (or parchment paper).
food.step 3: Combine together garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, salt, pepper, cumin and chili or Cayenne. Sprinkle seasoning over ribs and drizzle with oil. Rub the seasoning all over the ribs on both sides. Cover tray with foil and bake for 2 hours.
food.step 4: During the last 5 minutes of cook time, mix together sauce ingredients.
food.step 5: Remove ribs from the oven, remove foil and spread the tops of the ribs with the barbecue sauce mixture.
food.step6: Increase oven temperature to 460°F (240°C). Return ribs to the oven, uncovered, and bake for a further 10 minutes. Change oven settings to broil (or grill) on medium-high heat to lightly char and caramelise the edges (about 3 minutes)
food.step7: Rest for 10 minutes to allow the juices to recirculate back into the meat before slicing
food.step8: Enjoy!
food.ingredients: 4 pounds (2 kg) baby back pork ribs
food.time: Preparation Time : 30 min, Cooking Time: 90 min
food.description: BBQ Ribs are country-styled ribs of Pork that are seasoned and boiled until tender , and then baked with a barbeque sauce with a kick of garlic and optional heat.

food.recipe: This is like the best ham and cheese sandwich you will ever have and that’s all I need to say about it. (But since I am me I will say a little more.) Try to get really good ham if you can find it. Serrano ham is the Spanish equivalent of Prosciutto di Parma, and goes really well with the slightly sharp Manchego cheese
food.step 1: Heat the olive oil over medium heat in a small saucepan.
food.step 2: Cut a slit in the peppers and fry them in the oil until tender and crispy.
food.step 3: Set the peppers on a paper towel and sprinkle them with salt. Set aside.
food.step 4: Fry the pork loin in the oil until it's cooked through and golden brown.
food.step 5: Slice the baguette/roll in half and toast lightly.
food.step6: Drizzle each side with a bit of olive oil.
food.step7: Place the peppers, pork loin, ham and tomatoes between the bread to assemble the bocadillo.
food.step8: Serve with mojo picón or garlic alioli on the side.
food.ingredients: Good crusty bread (half a baguette or a large bread roll)
food.description: The bocadillo or bocata, in Spain, is a sandwich made with Spanish bread, usually a baguette or similar type of bread, cut lengthwise. Traditionally seen as a humble food, its low cost has allowed it to evolve over time into an iconic piece of cuisine. In Spain, they are often eaten in cafes and tapas bars.

food.recipe: It’s a fantastic starting point for curries, stir fries, fried rice, and more, and its earthy, nutty flavor is even delicious on its own
food.step 1: Combine the rinsed rice, water, and olive oil in a pot and bring to a boil. Cover, reduce the heat, and simmer for 45 minutes.
food.step 2: Remove from the heat and let it sit, covered for 10 more minutes. Fluff with a fork.
food.ingredients: 1 cup uncooked brown rice, well rinsed
food.description: Brown rice and white rice have similar amounts of calories and carbohydrates. Brown rice is a whole grain and a good source of magnesium, phosphorus, selenium, thiamine, niacin, vitamin B6, and manganese, and is high in fiber. ... Brown rice is whole rice from which only the husk (the outermost layer) is removed.

food.recipe: These brownies always turn out!
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour an 8-inch square pan.
food.step 2: In a large saucepan, melt 1/2 cup butter. Remove from heat, and stir in sugar, eggs, and 1 teaspoon vanilla. Beat in 1/3 cup cocoa, 1/2 cup flour, salt, and baking powder. Spread batter into prepared pan.
food.step 3: Bake in preheated oven for 25 to 30 minutes. Do not overcook.
food.step 4: To Make Frosting: Combine 3 tablespoons softened butter, 3 tablespoons cocoa, honey, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, and 1 cup confectioners' sugar. Stir until smooth. Frost brownies while they are still warm.
food.description: Fudgy, chewy squares that have been satisfying chocolate cravings since the 19th century.

food.recipe: Delicious, buttery, melt in your mouth puff pastry pinwheels stuffed with Butter Chicken Simmer Sauce, chicken and cheese. They are perfect for your parties, brunches and special events.
food.step 1: Pre-heat the oven at 350 F.  In a large bowl, mix together chopped onion, shredded chicken and salt – set aside.  Lay one sheet of the thawed puff pastry flat on a baking sheet.
food.step 2: Spread 3 Tbsp of Butter Chicken Sauce over the pastry, covering evenly to the edges.
food.step 3: Layer 1/2 of the onion-chicken mixture evenly over the sauce. Now, sprinkle ½ cup cheese all over the chicken
food.step 4: Starting from the edges, roll the stuffed Puff Pastry sheet into a log shape. Take a sharp knife and cut the log shaped Puff Pastry into 1.5-inch thick pinwheels.
food.step 5: Lay pinwheels on a baking sheet covered with parchment paper and brush tops with beaten egg.
food.ingredients: 6 Tbsp Sutter Buttes Butter Chicken Simmer Sauce
food.ingredient 2: 1 Package Puff Pastry Sheet (contains 2 sheets per package)
food.ingredient 5: 1 Cup Shredded Cheese – can use any variety as per choice.
food.description: Delicious, buttery, melt in your mouth puff pastry pinwheels stuffed with Butter Chicken Simmer Sauce, chicken and cheese. They are perfect for your parties, brunches and special events.

food.recipe: Cake Mix Cookies are an easy cookie recipe that you can mix and match cake flavors and add-ins! Mix in chocolate chips, M&Ms, sprinkles, peanut butter chips and more to your favorite cake mix flavor and get creative!
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and set aside.
food.step 2: n a large bowl mix together cake mix, eggs, and oil until smooth. Alternately you can do this step in the bowl of your stand mixer with the paddle attachment, mixing ingredients on low until combined.
food.step 3: Mix in desired add-ins until evenly incorporated.
food.step 4: Using a medium (2- tablespoon) cookie scoop portion the dough onto the prepared cookie sheet 2- inches apart. Bake for 9-10 minutes, or until lightly golden at the edges.
food.step 5: Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 3-4 minutes before transferring to a wire rack.
food.ingredient 4: 1 cup add-ins like chocolate chips or M&M’s (if adding in sprinkles use 1/2 cup)
food.description: A baking mix is a pre-mixed formulation of ingredients used for the cooking of baked goods. Baking mixes may be commercially manufactured or homemade. Baking mixes that cater to particular dietary needs, such as gluten-free baking mixes or kosher baking mixes, can be bought in many places.

food.recipe: The traditional caprese salad with a delicious twist! Replacing pesto with balsamic makes this great dish even better.
food.step 1: Assemble the salad onto a plate by layering the tomato slices, mozzarella, and basil leaves
food.step 2: Drizzle the pesto (as much as you like) over the salad and serve.
food.ingredients: 2 large tomatoes , sliced lengthwise into 1/4-inch thick slices
food.ingredient 2: 6 oz/170 g fresh mozzarella cheese , sliced into 1/4-inch thick slices
food.restaurants: ["celini","mezzo mezzo","botticino","prego","mia cucina","gustoso","little italy","cincin mumbai'","quatrro ristorante","olio novotel","romano's","out of the blue"]
food.description: Caprese salad is a simple Italian salad, made of sliced fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, and sweet basil, seasoned with salt and olive oil, occasionally paired with arugula. It is usually arranged on a plate in restaurant practice. Like pizza Margherita, it features the colours of the Italian flag: green, white, and red.

food.recipe: With its outstanding spice flavor, super moist crumb, and velvety cream cheese frosting, this is truly the best carrot cake. Use brown sugar and toasted pecans for deeper flavor.
food.step 1: Make the cake: Preheat oven to 300°F (149°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Spread the chopped pecans on the sheet and toast for 7-8 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 10-15 minutes.
food.step 2: Turn the oven up to 350°F (177°C). Grease two or three 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans.
food.step 3: Whisk the brown sugar, granulated sugar, oil, eggs, applesauce, and vanilla together in a large bowl until combined and no brown sugar lumps remain. In another large bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and cloves together. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and, using a rubber spatula or wooden spoon, fold the ingredients together until just combined. Fold in the carrots and 1 cup of the toasted pecans. (The rest of the pecans are for garnish.)
food.step 4: Pour/spoon the batter evenly into the cake pans. If using three cake pans, bake for 20-24 minutes. If using two cake pans, bake for 30-35 minutes. Test the center with a toothpick. If it comes out clean, the cakes are done. If not, continue to bake until cooked through. Do not over-bake. Allow the cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.
food.step 5: Make the frosting: In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners’ sugar, cream/milk, vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Add more confectioners’ sugar if frosting is too thin, more milk if frosting is too thick, or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Frosting should be soft, but not runny.
food.step6: Assemble and frost: First, using a large serrated knife or cake leveler, layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with frosting. Top with 2nd layer, more frosting, and then top with the 3rd layer. Spread remaining frosting all over the top and sides. Decorate the sides and top of the cake with the remaining toasted pecans. Refrigerate cake for at least 15-20 minutes before slicing. This helps the cake hold its shape when cutting.
food.step7: Cover leftover frosted cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.
food.ingredients: 2 cups (260g) chopped pecans (1 cup for cake, 1 cup for garnish. Nuts are optional. )
food.ingredient 2: 1 and 1/2 cups (300g) packed light or dark brown sugar
food.ingredient 4: 1 cup (240ml) vegetable oil or canola oil (or melted coconut oil)
food.restaurants: ["Girgaon Katta","Prakash Shakahari Upahaar Kendra","Vinay Health Home","Nav Gomantak","Aaswad","Diva Maharashtracha","Marutirao Misalwale","Shree Krishna Batatawada","Wagh Bakri Tea Lounge","amey","I Love Misal"]
food.description: Carrot cake is cake that contains carrots mixed into the batter. Most modern carrot cake recipes have a white cream cheese frosting.

food.recipe: These crisps taste fabulous -- but they are ridiculously simple to make.
food.step 1: Preheat oven to 425° F. Spray a baking sheet with cooking oil and then top with parchment paper.
food.step 2: Drop the cheddar cheese in mounds of 1 tbsp each, spreading each out into an even layer. Also, leave about 1-inch of space between each cheese round. Sprinkle with a touch of cayenne pepper (not too much!).
food.step 3: Bake for 6-10 minutes, watching carefully. You want the cheese to melt and just about stop bubbling. Do NOT let it brown though, as it will be bitter.
food.step 4: Remove from the baking sheet and arrange on a plate. Serve.
food.description: These cheese crisps are gluten-free and keto-friendly, and taste like a potato chip had a child with some cheddar cheese!

food.recipe: This is a great recipe for parties. I freeze the leftovers; they reheat quite well. The zesty chicken and cooked peppers are a succulent delight when mixed with the melted cheeses. Cut the quesadillas into wedges and serve with sour cream and salsa.
food.step 1: Heat 1 tablespoon of the olive oil in a skillet over high heat. Sprinkle the chicken with salt, pepper and taco seasoning. Add the chicken to the skillet and saute over medium-high heat until done, about 4 minute per side. Remove from the skillet and dice into cubes. Set aside.
food.step 2: Add the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil to the skillet over high heat. Throw in the onions and peppers and cook until the peppers have a few dark brown/black areas, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove and set aside.
food.step 3: Sizzle 1/2 tablespoon of the butter in a separate skillet or griddle over medium heat and lay a flour tortilla in the skillet. Then build the quesadillas by laying grated cheese on the bottom tortilla, and then arranging the chicken and cooked peppers. Top with a little more grated cheese and top with a second tortilla.
food.step 4: When the tortilla is golden on the first side, carefully flip the quesadilla to the other side, adding another 1/2 tablespoon butter to the skillet at the same time. Continue cooking until the second side is golden. Repeat with the remaining tortillas and fillings.
food.step 5: Cut each quesadilla into wedges and serve with Pico de Gallo.
food.step6: Dice up equal quantities of tomatoes and onions. Roughly chop the cilantro.
food.step7: Now, slice 1 or 2 jalapenos in half. With a spoon, scrape out the seeds. (If you like things spicy, leave in some of the white membranes.) Dice the jalapenos very finely; you want a hint of heat and jalapeno flavor, but you don't want to cause any fires. Now dump the four ingredients into a bowl.
food.step8: Slice the lime in half and squeeze the juice from half the lime into the bowl. Sprinkle with salt, and stir together until combined. Be sure to taste the pico de gallo and adjust the seasonings, adding salt or more diced jalapeno if needed.
food.ingredient 3: 2 1/2 cups grated cheese (Monterey Jack is the best)
food.ingredient 5: Pico de Gallo, for serving, recipe follows
food.ingredient 7: 2 tablespoons taco or Cajun seasoning mix
food.ingredient 8: 1 large onion, cut in half and then into slices
food.ingredient 9: 1 red bell pepper, seeded and sliced into strips
food.ingredient 12: 12 Roma tomatoes (slightly under ripe is fine
food.restaurants: ["NewYork Burrito Company","Piping Hot","Poetry By Love & Cheesecake"]
food.description: A quesadilla is a Mexican dish, different from a taco, consisting of a tortilla that is filled primarily with cheese, and sometimes meats, beans, and spices, and then cooked on a griddle.

food.recipe: This recipe sticks very much to the original, only minorly changing the ingredients and cooking method to bring it in line with the times
food.step 1: Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F.
food.step 2: Heat the olive oil in a large Dutch oven. Add the bacon and cook over medium heat for 8 to 10 minutes, until lightly browned. Remove the bacon to a plate with a slotted spoon.
food.step 3: Meanwhile, lay the chicken out on paper towels and pat dry. Liberally sprinkle the chicken on both sides with salt and pepper. When the bacon is removed, brown the chicken pieces in batches in a single layer for about 5 minutes, turning to brown evenly. Remove the chicken to the plate with the bacon and continue to brown until all the chicken is done. Set aside.
food.step 4: Add the carrots, onions, 2 teaspoons salt, and 1 teaspoon pepper to the pan and cook over medium heat for 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are lightly browned. Add the garlic and cook for 1 more minute. Add the Cognac and put the bacon, chicken, and any juices that collected on the plate into the pot. Add the wine, chicken stock, and thyme and bring to a simmer. Cover the pot with a tight fitting lid and place in the oven for 30 to 40 minutes, until the chicken is just not pink. Remove from the oven and place on top of the stove.
food.step 5: Mash 1 tablespoon of butter and the flour together and stir into the stew. Add the frozen onions. In a medium saute pan, add the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter and cook the mushrooms over medium-low heat for 5 to 10 minutes, until browned. Add to the stew. Bring the stew to a simmer and cook for another 10 minutes. Season to taste. Serve hot.
food.ingredient 2: 4 ounces good bacon or pancetta, diced
food.ingredient 4: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
food.ingredient 5: 1/2 pound carrots, cut diagonally in 1-inch pieces
food.ingredient 9: 1/2 bottle (375 ml) good dry red wine such as Burgundy
food.ingredient 10: 1 cup good chicken stock, preferably homemade
food.ingredient 12: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature, divided
food.ingredient 15: 1/2 pound cremini mushrooms, stems removed and thickly sliced
food.description: It is a French dish of chicken braised with wine, lardons, mushrooms, and optionally garlic. A red Burgundy wine is typically used,[2] though many regions of France make variants using local wines, such as coq au vin jaune (Jura), coq au Riesling (Alsace), coq au pourpre or coq au violet (Beaujolais nouveau), coq au Champagne, etc.

food.recipe: Kacchi Dabeli or Kutchi dabeli is a Mumbai street food also popular in Gujarat.
food.step 1: Dry roast the red chili, cumin, cloves, cinnamon and coriander seeds.
food.step 2: Add all the ingredients in a dry grinder.
food.step 3: Grind to a fine powder. keep aside.
food.step 4: In a wet grinder or blender, grind the soaked red chilies, garlic, lemon juice and salt to a smooth paste.
food.step 5: Add water if required. Keep aside.
food.step6: Boil the potatoes in a pressure cooker or microwave oven.
food.step7: Peel and mash them and keep aside.
food.step8: In a pan or kadai, heat oil. Add cumin.
food.step9: Then add chopped onion and fry the onions till they become soft.
food.step10: Add asafoetida/hing and fry for a minute on a low flame.
food.step11: Add the sweet tamarind dates chutney to the onions and mix well.
food.step12: Add the mashed potatoes and again mix well.
food.step13: Add the dabeli masala powder to the mashed potatoes. Mix well and add salt.
food.ingredient 2: 1 teaspoon coriander seeds or coriander powder
food.ingredient 6: 1 to 2 red chilies - soaked in warm water for 30-40 minutes
food.ingredient 10: 3 medium sized potatoes - boiled, peeled and mashed
food.ingredient 12: 2 teaspoon dabeli masala2 teaspoon dabeli masala
food.ingredient 18: ¼ cup chopped coriander leaves (cilantro leaves)
food.time: Prep Time : 10 min , Cook Time : 70 min
food.description: Dabeli, kutchi dabeli or double roti is a popular snack food of India, originating in the Kutch or Kachchh region of Gujarat.

food.recipe: A Devil's Food Cake is an American classic. With its almost black color, it is probably the most 'chocolately' of the chocolate cakes. To go with that rich chocolate flavor is a cake with a wonderfully soft crumb that is dense and moist. For a double dose of chocolate we fill and frost this cake with a fudgy chocolate frosting. Mmmm. While no one knows for sure how it got its name "Devil's" Food Cake, one opinion is that it's because it's just too sinful
food.step 1: To make the frosting: Put the chocolate in a large heatproof bowl. In a small saucepan, bring the cream to a boil. Pour the cream over the chocolate, move the bowl gently to let the cream settle. Set the mixture aside until softened, about 4 minutes. Whisk until smooth. Cover the surface of the frosting with plastic wrap. Set aside and let set up at room temperature, about 2 hours.
food.step 2: To make the cake: Set a rack in the middle of the oven and preheat to 350 degrees F. Lightly butter two 9-inch round cake pans and line the bottoms with a circle of parchment or wax paper.
food.step 3: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
food.step 4: In a standing mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter at medium speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Increase the speed to medium-high and slowly add the sugar. Continue beating until light and smooth, about 4 minutes. Turn the mixer off and scrape down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula. Add the cocoa powder and vanilla and beat at medium speed for 1 minute more. (Stop the machine and scrape down the sides of the bowl again, if needed.) With the mixer running at medium-low speed, add the eggs, one at a time, beating for 1 minute between each addition. Scrape down the sides of the bowl.
food.step 5: Combine the water and milk in a saucepan and bring just to a boil. Remove from the heat.
food.step6: With the mixer at low speed, add the flour mixture, about a 1/4 cup at a time. Carefully pour the hot liquid into the batter. Remove the bowl from the mixer and, using a large rubber spatula, finish combining the batter until smooth. Divide the batter evenly between the prepared pans. Lightly drop each pan onto the counter to settle the batter.
food.step7: Set the pans on the middle rack in the oven. Bake until the cakes begin to pull away from the sides of the pans and the center springs back when touched lightly, about 30 to 35 minutes.
food.step8: Cool the cakes, in the pans, on a rack for 10 minutes. Turn the cake layers out of the pans and cool on the rack. (If not assembling the cake right away, wrap the layers in plastic wrap and store at room temperature for up to 1 day, or freeze for up to 2 months.)
food.step9: Assemble the Devil's Food Cake. Place 1 cake layer upside-down on a cake stand or flat plate. Scoop about 1/3 of the icing onto the center of the layer. Using a large, offset spatula, spread the icing evenly over the layer to the edges. Place the other cake layer, rounded-side up, on top. Evenly spread half of the remaining icing over the top, spreading any excess icing down the sides. Spread the remaining icing around the sides of the cake. Use the tip of the offset spatula to make a swirling pattern in the icing. Serve. Store under a cake dome or loosely wrapped with plastic, at room temperature, for up to 2 days.
food.ingredient 7: 12 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature, plus more for the pans

food.recipe: A traditional Chinese sweet similar to halva or cotton candy made from fine white sugar, peanuts, desiccated coconut, white sesame seeds, corn syrup and glutinous rice flour.
food.step 1: Place the oil and the sesame seeds into a blender and continue to blend until you have a smooth liquid. Pour into a pan and add the flour. Stir over high heat until it thickens.
food.step 2: Continue to stir over the heat for another minute and then remove from the heat.
food.step 3: Fill one baking tray with rice and top it with another baking tray. Place this in the oven at 80C (176 degrees Fahrenheit).
food.step 4: Put the sugar, vinegar, glucose syrup and water into a pan and heat on high heat. Wash down the sides of the pan using a wet pastry brush to get rid of any sugar crystals. Add a candy thermometer and leave it unstirred until it reaches 133C (271.4 degrees Fahrenheit).
food.step 5: Grab your trays out of the oven and rub the top one with oil, this one has the warm rice underneath it so that it stays warm while we work.
food.step6: Pour the sugar syrup on top and using a spatula move it around as it cools so the edges don’t set hard.
food.step7: Put on cotton gloves and then 2 pairs of silicone gloves to protect your hands.
food.step8: Once the syrup is very thick roll it into a ball. Make a hole in the centre, using your thumbs. Gently squeeze and make that into a bigger circle trying to make sure it is even without any thin bits. Continue to stretch it into a larger ring. Letting it rest on the warm oiled surface keeps it soft.
food.step9: Flip over one side to make a figure of 8 then bring one side over on top of the other. Now we have 2 stands, stretch that out and gently pull then make and 8 again and pull again now we have 4 stands. Repeat that four more times.
food.step10: Pour the warm sesame paste into the middle. Continue to twist and pull dipping it into the paste each time for another 8 turns. Now you will have 16.384 strands of pashmak.
food.ingredients: Sesame paste made with 150g (5.29 ounces) sesame seeds
food.ingredient 8: 2 baking trays and rice to fill tray
food.description: Dragon's beard candy is a handmade traditional art of China. It is also a traditional Chinese sweet similar to floss halva or cotton candy, which can be found in many Chinese communities.

food.recipe: One of my favorite things about Italian cuisine is that is so regional. When traveling from one region to the next across the country, you’ll find that the cuisine changes dramatically, depending on the region’s location, climate, and the people within. Although I chose to make Umbria our home, I’ve always had a love for Puglia, and over the years, and we try to visit Puglia as often as we can
food.step 1: In a large bowl mix together the flour, yeast, potatoes, oil, and salt, then add just enough warm water to create a dough
food.step 2: Dump the dough onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 5 to 7 minutes, or until smooth and shiny.
food.step 3: Place the dough into a lightly oiled bowl and cover with plastic wrap.
food.step 4: Place the dough into a lightly oiled bowl and cover with plastic wrap.
food.step 5: Place the bowl in a warm spot in the kitchen, and let rise until doubled in size, about 1 hour.
food.step6: Preheat oven to 450 degrees F.
food.step7: Lightly oil a 14 inch round baking pan and press the dough in to fit.
food.step8: Press your fingertips over the top of the dough to create dimples.
food.step9: Place the olives and tomatoes over the dough, then sprinkle with the oregano and coarse salt.
food.step10: Drizzle with olive oil, let rest for 30 minutes, then bake until golden brown, about 20 to 25 minutes.
food.step11: Cool to room temperature before slicing.
food.description: Focaccia Barese {Focaccia From Bari} ... In Bari, the focaccia is often made with mashed potatoes, and then is topped with ripe tomatoes, oregano, olive oil, and sometimes olives. This focaccia is great served with soup, can be enjoyed throughout the day as a snack, and is wonderful cut into wedges and packed for a picnic.

food.recipe: Focaccia is the quintessential snack of Bari. Summers along the Barese coast wouldn’t be the same without focaccia – it’s the perfect beach food! – though the same could be said for mid-morning or afternoon snacks at any time of the year. Bakeries all over Bari have it on display from the wee hours of the morning while streets are filled with its tempting scent.
food.step 1: Melt butter and add garlic in a medium sauce pan.
food.step 2: Cook over medium for 1 minute.
food.step 3: Add flour and cook 1 minute, stirring constantly.
food.step 4: Stir in broth and milk and cook, stirring frequently, until sauce boils and thickens.
food.step 5: Add parsley, salt, pepper and cheese.
food.step6: Stir until cheese is melted.
food.step7: Toss hot pasta with sauce and serve immediately.
food.ingredients: (1 lb) box penne or (1 lb) box penne rigate, cooked as directed, drained and kept hot
food.ingredient 4: cup chicken broth or 3/4 cup beef broth
food.description: CREAMY GARLIC PENNE PASTA - Quick & Easy, Family Favorite ... A traditional Alfredo sauce doesn't have any flour at all

food.food_item: goat milk and corn panna cotta with blackberries
food.recipe: This delicately sweet and tangy panna cotta from Top Chef winner Brooke Williamson is the perfect way to showcase plump summer fruits. We use blackberries here, but you could also swap in strawberries, raspberries or juicy sliced peaches
food.step 1: Cut the kernels off the corncobs and transfer to a blender; reserve 3 of the cobs. Puree the kernels until smooth, 1 to 2 minutes. Strain the puree through a fine sieve set over a medium bowl, pressing on the solids; discard the solids. You should have about 1 cup of corn juice.
food.step 2: In a medium saucepan, whisk the corn juice with the goat milk, heavy cream, honey, vanilla bean paste, thyme sprigs and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Add the reserved corncobs and bring to a simmer over low heat. Remove from the heat and let steep for 10 minutes, then discard the corncobs and strain the panna cotta base through a fine sieve set over a medium bowl.
food.step 3: In a small bowl, sprinkle the gelatin over 3 tablespoons of water and let stand until softened, about 3 minutes. Whisk the gelatin mixture into the strained panna cotta base until dissolved, then strain again through a fine sieve set over a large measuring cup with a spout.
food.step 4: Lightly grease six 6-ounce ramekins with nonstick spray and set them on a rimmed baking sheet. Fill the ramekins with the panna cotta base, cover and refrigerate until set, at least 4 hours or overnight.
food.step 5: In a medium bowl, toss the blackberries with the sugar, lemon zest and juice, the thyme leaves and a pinch of salt. Let stand until juicy, about 1 hour.
food.step6: Run a knife around the panna cottas and invert onto plates. Top with the blackberries and caramel corn; serve immediately.
food.ingredients: 5 ears of corn, preferably white, shucked
food.ingredient 6: 3 thyme sprigs, plus 1 teaspoon thyme leave
food.ingredient 11: 1/4 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest plus 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
food.description: This delicately sweet and tangy panna cotta is the perfect way to showcase plump summer fruits.

food.recipe: Grilled jalapeños stuffed with sausage and cheese bring the heat, the sweet, and the smokiness for a flavor bomb appetizer that's perfect for your next grilling night, or your next tailgate!
food.step 1: Soak a large handful of toothpicks in water for at least 10-15 minutes as you prep the jalapeños.
food.step 2: Slice the jalapeños in half lengthwise, then remove the seeds and membranes. Set aside. (Use latex gloves to do this if you are sensitive to the heat of the jalapeños!)
food.step 3: In a large bowl, mix the sausage, cream cheese, shredded cheeses, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper. Use a fork to thoroughly mash all of the ingredients together until very well blended.
food.step 4: Scoop about 1-2 tablespoons of the sausage and cheese mixture into each hollowed jalapeño. Gently press the mixture into the jalapeño to fill it, and create a mound of mixture protruding from the jalapeño. Repeat with each jalapeño.
food.step 5: Wrap each stuffed jalapeño in one strip of bacon, and use the soaked toothpicks to hold the bacon in place where needed.
food.step6: Set your oven to preheat at 375, then take the jalapeños outside to grill. Grill over medium-high heat for about 5-6 minutes per side, until bacon is charred and thoroughly cooked. Transfer jalapeños to a baking dish, and cook at 375 F in the oven to finish cooking the sausage mixtures inside, and further brown the bacon.
food.step7: Carefully remove all toothpicks, and serve hot!
food.ingredient 2: 8 ounces Hatfield® Recipe Essentials Sweet Italian Ground Sausage
food.ingredient 4: 2 ounces sharp cheddar cheese shredded from a block of cheese
food.ingredient 5: 2 ounces pepper jack cheese shredded from a block of cheese
food.ingredient 10: 16 strips bacon use your favorite (I used thick cut, but any cut works!)
food.description: The rich and creamy combination of bacon, cream cheese, and cheddar is a nice foil for the muted spice of grilled jalapeño peppers.

food.recipe: This classic hamburger is made with only 4 ingredients and can be grilled or cooked on the stove top!
food.step 1: Mix beef, onion and Worcestershire in a bowl just until combined.
food.step 2: Gently shape into 4 patties, about ¾" thick. Using your thumb, create an indent in the center of each burger.Gently shape into 4 patties, about ¾" thick. Using your thumb, create an indent in the center of each burger.
food.step 3: Refrigerate at least 20 minutes before cooking.
food.step 4: Preheat grill to medium heat.
food.step 5: Season the outside of the burgers with salt & pepper to taste.
food.step6: Cook burgers about 4-6 minutes per side or until they reach 160°F.
food.step7: Rest 5 minutes. Serve on toasted sesame seed rolls.
food.step8: Heat a cast-iron pan over medium-high heat.
food.step9: Season the outside of the burgers with salt & pepper to taste.
food.step10: Add 1 tablespoon olive oil to the pan. Add the beef patties and cook 5-6 minutes per side or until they reach 160°F.
food.description: A hamburger is a sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun. It is usually served with cheese , lettuce and tomatoes and ketchup.

food.recipe: This Hibachi Style Fried Rice is the perfect restaurant version that can be made at home with few ingredients. Simple, filling, and delicious. Try making it home to share with your family.
food.step 1: Add butter in a wok.
food.step 2: Add onion and garlic and fry for a minute.
food.step 3: Now add peas and carrots and saute for a minute.
food.step 4: Push the veggies on the side.
food.step 5: Add whisked eggs in the wok and scramble them.
food.step6: Mix the scrambled eggs with the veggies.
food.step7: Add cooked rice, salt, white pepper powder, soy sauce and toasted sesame oil and toss well.
food.step8: Serve hot with yum yum sauce.
food.description: Hibachi is a hot plate / stove / griddle. Fried rice is rice mixed with oil, soy, and egg (and some other ingredients)

food.recipe: Hong dou tang, or sweet red bean soup, is a home-y Cantonese dessert soup. This one is served with unfilled tong yuen, or chewy mochi balls.
food.step 1: In a large pot over medium heat, add the red beans and 8 cups of water. Let simmer for 2-2.5 hours, or until some of the beans are broken down. I like some of them whole, but you can let the beans cook longer if you like them more broken down.
food.step 2: While the soup is cooking, mix the rice flour with 7 T warm water until the mixture is homogeneous; it may be a little dry, but you'd rather it be too dry than too wet.
food.step 3: Split the dough in half, and roll each half into a log, then cut each log into 40 pieces. Roll each piece into a smooth ball (you may need to massage the dough a little bit to get it to stick together). You may be tempted to skip the ball forming step, but this will make sure the dough doesn't fall apart in the soup later.
food.step 4: Once the beans are done to your desired consistency, add the tong yuen. Stir to make sure the tong yuen don't stick together. Once the tong yuen float to the top of the soup, 3-5 minutes, they'r ready!
food.step 5: Serve the hong dou tang, making sure to spoon some beans and some tong yuen into each serving. You can add a splash of milk or cream to make it creamier, if you'd like.
food.description: Hong dou tang or red bean soup is a popular Chinese dish served in Mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. It is categorized as a tang shui or sweet soup. It is often served cold during the summer, and hot in the winter. Leftover red bean soup can also be frozen to make ice pops and is a popular dessert.

food.recipe: From summer barbecues through to Bonfire Night, hot dogs will never go out of style. Check out our super sausage recipes and find topping and sauce inspiration, including classic fried onions and next level accompaniments
food.step 1: Gather the ingredients.
food.step 2: In a food processor, purée the onion, garlic, coriander, paprika, mustard seed, marjoram, and mace. Add the milk, egg white, sugar, salt, and pepper and combine well. Remove to a bowl and set aside
food.step 3: One at a time, grind the pork, beef, and fat cubes through the fine blade of a meat grinder. Combine the three and grind them together.
food.step 4: In a large bowl, combine the puréed seasonings with the meat and mix with your hands. Wet your hands with cold water to prevent the mixture from sticking.
food.step 5: Refrigerate the mixture for 30 minutes and then grind it again. Prepare the casings.
food.step6: Meanwhile, rinse the casing well under cool running water to remove the salt. Place it in a bowl of cool water and soak it for 30 minutes.
food.step7: After soaking, run cool water over the casing. Slip one end of the casing over the faucet nozzle and firmly hold it in place. Turn on the cold water, gently at first, and then more forcefully. This will flush out any salt in the casing and help you spot any breaks. Should you find one, simply snip out a small section of the casing.
food.step8: Put the casing in a bowl of water and add a splash of white vinegar. (A tablespoon of vinegar per cup of water is sufficient.) The vinegar softens the casing and makes it more transparent, which in turn makes the hot dog look nicer. Leave the casing in the water and vinegar solution until you are ready to use it. Rinse it well and drain before stuffing.
food.step9: Using a sausage stuffer, fill the casings with the meat mixture and twist them off into 6-inch links
food.step10: Parboil the links (but don't separate them) in simmering water for 20 minutes.
food.step11: Place the ​franks in a bowl of ice water and chill. Remove, pat dry, and refrigerate. You can refrigerate them for up to 1 week or freeze them for future use.
food.ingredient 15: 4 feet sheep casings (or small hog casings, about 1 1/2-inch diameter)
food.description: The hot dog is a grilled or steamed sausage sandwich where the sausage is served in the slit of a partially sliced bun. It can also refer to the sausage itself. The sausage used is the wiener or frankfurter. The names of these sausages also commonly refer to their assembled sandwiches.

food.recipe: At the risk of sounding like a well-known chef from Gloucestershire, jam roly poly is a ‘proper’ old school dessert and will brighten up anyone’s day, especially when served on a cold and grey one. Traditionally, roly polies are wrapped in muslin or foil and steamed, but this recipe does without that extra faff by going straight down the baking route
food.step 1: Preheat the oven to 200C/180C Fan/Gas 6. Butter a large sheet of baking paper and set aside.
food.step 2: Stir the flour, suet, sugar and salt in a large bowl until fully combined. Slowly stir in the milk to form a soft, spongy dough.
food.step 3: Tip the dough out onto a floured surface and knead for a few minutes. Roll the dough out to a 22cm x 32cm/8½in x 13in rectangle.
food.step 4: Spread the jam onto the dough, leaving a 1.5cm/½in border. Gently roll the dough up from the short end and transfer to the greaseproof paper, seam-side down. Wrap the roly poly in the baking paper, making a long pleat in the paper to allow the pudding to expand as it cooks. Twist the ends of the paper like a Christmas cracker and tie tightly with kitchen string, to seal the pudding inside. Repeat the process with a large piece of kitchen foil.
food.step 5: Place the pudding onto a roasting rack set on a deep-sided roasting tin. Pour boiling water halfway up the roasting tin and cook in the oven for 30–35 minutes.
food.step6: Remove the pudding from the oven, unwrap the kitchen foil, then snip the string and unwrap the paper.
food.step7: The pudding should be well risen and lightly browned in places. Don’t worry if the jam has made its way through to the outside of the pudding a little – it will taste all the more delicious.
food.step8: Put on a board or serving plate and cut into thick slices. Serve with lots of hot custard or cream.
food.ingredient 2: 200g/7oz self-raising flour, plus extra for dusting
food.description: Jam roly-poly, shirt-sleeve pudding, dead man's arm or dead man's leg is a traditional British pudding probably first created in the early 19th century. It is a flat-rolled suet pudding, which is then spread with jam and rolled up, similar to a Swiss roll, then steamed or baked.

food.recipe: Kachoris are basically deep fried breads. There are many varieties of kachori recipes in the Indian cuisine and moong dal kachori is a popular one
food.step 1: Take 2 cups all purpose flour (maida) and salt in a bowl or pan. mix very well.
food.step 2: Add ¼ cup ghee.
food.step 3: With your fingertips mix the ghee with the flour for a few minutes till you get a breadcrumb like texture in the mixture.
food.step 4: Add water in parts and knead the dough till soft.
food.step 5: Cover the dough with a moist muslin or kitchen towel and let it rest for 30 minutes
food.step6: Rinse ½ cup moong dal in a bowl. Soak moong dal with enough water for 2 hours.
food.step7: Later drain all the water very well and add the soaked moong lentils in a grinder jar
food.step8: Grind to a roughly coarse mixture.
food.step9: Then heat a pan. Add ½ tablespoon ghee.
food.step10: Once the ghee melts, keep the flame to the lowest or switch off the flame.
food.step11: Add all the spice powders one by one.
food.step12: Keep the flame to its lowest and mix very well. do make sure that the spices do not burn.
food.step13: Then add the coarsely ground moong dal. Also add salt and 1 pinch of asafoetida.
food.ingredient 4: ½ cup water or add as required
food.ingredient 10: ½ teaspoon dry ginger powder (saunth powder)
food.description: It is a sweet dish dipped in sugar syrup. In Gujarat, it is usually a round ball made of flour and dough filled with a stuffing of yellow moong dal, black pepper, red chili powder, and ginger paste. In Delhi it is often served as chaat. Delhi also has another kind of kachori, called 'Khasta kachori' or 'Raj Kachori'.

food.recipe: Popular Indian sweet, Kaju Katli is a fudge made out of cashews. The homemade version is so much better than the store bought!
food.step 1: Place cashews in a spice grinder. I prefer using my spice grinder (this is the one I have) to grind nuts. You can also use a food processor or any other blender you have.
food.step 2: Grind to a smooth powder. However don't over grind it else cashews will release oil, you don't want cashew butter!
food.step 3: Add sugar and water in a pan on medium heat. You can also add rose water (optional) at this point. Stir to combine
food.step 4: Let the sugar melt and then once the sugar melts, let the mixture boil for 1 minute. We are not looking for any sugar syrup consistent here.
food.step 5: Then lower the heat and add in the powdered cashews. Stir to combine.
food.step6: Keep stirring the mixture on low heat. Add a teaspoon of ghee and stir. Ghee makes the mixture smooth and also adds some shine to the katli.
food.step7: Keep stirring, after around 10 minutes on low heat, the dough will leave the sides of the pan. This is the stage when you want to remove pan from heat.
food.step8: It means your dough is done. If not, you need to cook it further. It will be done around 10-12 minutes on low heat though.
food.step9: Once the dough is done, transfer it to a sheet of parchment paper.
food.step10: Wait for 3 to 4 minutes for the dough to cool down a bit. Then knead the dough with your hands to make it smooth. You have to knead the dough while its warm. But be careful to not burn your fingers. Let it cool down a little and only then attempt to knead.
food.step11: Then place another sheet of parchment paper on top of the dough. Roll to 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick using a rolling pin applying equal pressure on all sides.
food.step12: Once rolled, apply chandi vark if using. Cut the dough into diamond shape by first cutting the dough vertically and then horizontally.
food.ingredients: 1 cup whole cashews raw cashews, 150 grams
food.ingredient 6: edible silver leaves also known as chandi ka vark and is used for garnishing, optional
food.description: Kaju katli, also known as kaju barfi, is an Indian dessert similar to a barfi. Kaju means cashew; Barfi is often, but not always, made by thickening milk with sugar and other ingredients. Kesar kaju katli is a kaju katli recipe that includes saffron.

food.recipe: Rice kheer is a favorite Indian dessert made with basmati rice, milk, nuts and saffron. Rice kheer is also one of the most popular kheer variety made in North Indian cuisine along with Seviyan kheer and Phirni.
food.step 1: Meanwhile, when the rice grains are soaking, take 1 litre full fat milk in a heavy wide pan or saucepan or kadai.
food.step 2: Keep the pan on a low to medium-low flame. Stir at intervals so that the milk does not stick at the bottom of the pan.
food.step 3: Let the milk come to a boil.
food.step 4: Take 1 tablespoon milk from the pan in a small bowl. Let the milk become warm. Then add a few saffron strands in the milk. Keep aside.
food.step 5: After the milk begins to boil, drain all the water from the rice and add it to the hot boiling milk. mix very well.
food.step6: Simmer and cook rice on a low flame. No need to cover the pan when the rice is cooking.
food.step7: Cook the rice grains till they are 50% done or half-cooked.
food.step8: Then add 5 to 6 tbsp sugar or add as required. mix the sugar in the milk.
food.step9: Continue to cook rice on a low to medium-low flame. Do stir at intervals. simmer till the rice is almost cooked.
food.step10: Then add ½ teaspoon cardamom powder. add blanched & peeled sliced almonds and chopped cashews and sliced pistachios. mix well.
food.step11: Then add the saffron dissolved milk.
food.step12: Again mix and continue to cook on a low flame till the rice kheer thickens and the rice grains have completely cooked.
food.step13: Pour the rice kheer in individual serving bowls. You can serve the rice kheer, hot or warm or chilled. Refrigerate leftover rice kheer.
food.ingredient 2: 1 litre full fat milk or whole milk or full cream milk - 4 cups1 litre full fat milk or whole milk or full cream milk - 4 cups
food.ingredient 3: 6 tablespoons sugar or add as required
food.ingredient 4: ½ teaspoon cardamom powder or 5 to 6 green cardamoms powdered in mortar-pestle(choti elaichi powder)
food.ingredient 5: 1 pinch saffron strands (kesar) or 14 to 16 saffron strands
food.ingredient 6: 1 tablespoon chopped or sliced almonds or blanched almonds (badam)
food.ingredient 8: 1 tablespoon chopped or sliced unsalted pistachios (pista)
food.description: Kheer or firni is a pudding, originating from the Indian subcontinent, made by boiling milk and sugar with one of the following: rice, broken wheat, tapioca, vermicelli, or sweet corn. It is flavoured with cardamom, raisins, saffron, cashews, pistachios, almonds or other dry fruits and nuts

food.recipe: Kothimbir vadi is a delicious savory crisp snack made with gram flour (besan), coriander leaves and spices.
food.step 1: Heat a tawa or pan and keep the flame to a low or medium. Add ¼ cup peanuts.
food.step 2: Stir at intervals and roast till the peanuts become crunchy. The peanuts skin will also have some brown-black spots on them. Remove them in a plate and let them cool.
food.step 3: Rub the peanuts in your palms. This will remove the flaky skin. Now add the peanuts in a small grinder jar.
food.step 4: Grind to a coarse powder. Remove and keep aside.
food.step 5: In the same small grinder, add 1 teaspoon ginger, 1 teaspoon garlic and 2 green chilies (or 2 teaspoons green chilies).
food.step6: Add 1 to 2 tablespoon water and grind to a smooth paste. Keep aside. Alternatively you can even crush the garlic, ginger and green chilies in a mortar-pestle.
food.step7: Rinse coriander leaves very well. Drain the extra water and finely chop them. You will need 2 cups of finely chopped coriander leaves.
food.step8: Take the coriander leaves in a mixing bowl.
food.step9: Add the ginger+garlic+green chilli paste.
food.step10: Now add ¼ teaspoon turmeric powder, ¼ teaspoon red chili powder, ½ teaspoon coriander powder, ½ teaspoon cumin powder and 1 pinch of hing (optional).
food.step11: Next add the coarsely ground peanut powder and 1 tablespoon white sesame seeds.
food.step12: Add 1 cup besan (gram flour).
food.step13: Now add ½ teaspoon sugar (optional) and salt as required.
